articles.headline: Jan. 6 Panel Issues Subpoena to Trump, Setting Up Legal Battle Over Testimony
articles.snippet: While the former president has suggested he might testify live before the committee, it was far more likely that the demand would lead to a legal fight.
articles.abstract: While the former president has suggested he might testify live before the committee, it was far more likely that the demand would lead to a legal fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack issued a subpoena on Friday to Donald J. Trump, paving the way for a potentially historic court fight over whether Congress can compel testimony from a former president.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Twitter Tries Calming Employees as Deal With Elon Musk Looms
articles.snippet: With Mr. Musk’s $44 billion deal to buy Twitter set to close no later than Oct. 28, the company is trying to reassure workers about their employment and compensation.
articles.abstract: With Mr. Musk’s $44 billion deal to buy Twitter set to close no later than Oct. 28, the company is trying to reassure workers about their employment and compensation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twitter is trying to quell employees’ fears as Elon Musk’s looming takeover of the company fuels worries about a seismic overhaul of the social media service — but its assurances may only go so far.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger, Ryan Mac and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: Using Adoptions, Russia Turns Ukrainian Children Into Spoils of War
articles.snippet: Thousands of Ukrainian children have been transferred to Russia. “I didn’t want to go,” one girl told The New York Times from a foster home near Moscow.
articles.abstract: Thousands of Ukrainian children have been transferred to Russia. “I didn’t want to go,” one girl told The New York Times from a foster home near Moscow.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Russian forces laid siege to the Ukrainian city of Mariupol this spring, children fled bombed-out group homes and boarding schools. Separated from their families, they followed neighbors or strangers heading west, seeking the relative safety of central Ukraine.

articles.headline: China Hangs on Xi’s Every Word. His Silence Also Speaks Volumes.
articles.snippet: At the important Communist Party congress this week, the Chinese leader didn’t mention two long-repeated maxims. To many, it’s a warning of the turbulent times ahead.
articles.abstract: At the important Communist Party congress this week, the Chinese leader didn’t mention two long-repeated maxims. To many, it’s a warning of the turbulent times ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: As China’s leader, Xi Jinping, laid out his priorities this week for a breakthrough third term in power, officials parsed his words for signs of where the country was headed. What he did not say was as revealing.

articles.headline: Who Gets the Last Word on Steve Jobs? He Might.
articles.snippet: When Laurene Powell Jobs unveiled a website dedicated to the story of her late husband, historians wondered if it could change how influential people burnish their legacies.
articles.abstract: When Laurene Powell Jobs unveiled a website dedicated to the story of her late husband, historians wondered if it could change how influential people burnish their legacies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis meticulously curated the memory of her husband after he was assassinated, reimagining President John F. Kennedy as a fallen King Arthur in a modern-day Camelot.

articles.headline: Twitch’s Relationship With Its Streamers Shows Its Cracks
articles.snippet: The service recently said it was going to take a bigger cut of the money it shared with streamers. At an annual gathering in San Diego, they vented about the decision.
articles.abstract: The service recently said it was going to take a bigger cut of the money it shared with streamers. At an annual gathering in San Diego, they vented about the decision.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Twitch has wrestled with whether it could balance being a place where video game players could happily make good money from livestreaming to fans with becoming a profitable company.

articles.headline: For Trump’s Backers in Congress, ‘Devil Terms’ Help Rally Voters
articles.snippet: In vilifying tweets and speeches, G.O.P. lawmakers who contested the election have far outpaced other Republicans and Democrats in fueling polarization.
articles.abstract: In vilifying tweets and speeches, G.O.P. lawmakers who contested the election have far outpaced other Republicans and Democrats in fueling polarization.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Representative Mary Miller embarked on her first congressional campaign, she described herself in salt-of-the-earth, all-American terms: a mother, grandmother and farmer who embodied the “Midwestern values of faith, family and freedom.”
articles.byline: By Jennifer Valentino-DeVries and Steve Eder

articles.headline: Fears Over Fate of Democracy Leave Many Voters Frustrated and Resigned
articles.snippet: As democracy frays around them, Republicans and Democrats see different culprits and different risks.
articles.abstract: As democracy frays around them, Republicans and Democrats see different culprits and different risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: LA CROSSE, Wis. — Allyse Barba, a 34-year-old in the insurance industry, watched excitedly upstairs at Thrunie’s Classic Cocktails as Mandela Barnes, the youthful Democrat running for the Senate, tore through his stump speech just 19 days before the election.

articles.headline: Why Am I Seeing That Political Ad? Check Your ‘Trump Resistance’ Score.
articles.snippet: To help campaigns target ads, voter-profiling firms score millions of Americans on issues like guns, vaccines and QAnon.
articles.abstract: To help campaigns target ads, voter-profiling firms score millions of Americans on issues like guns, vaccines and QAnon.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the lead-up to the 2020 presidential election, a voter analytics firm called PredictWise came up with a novel approach to help Democratic campaigns target persuadable Republicans: “Covid concern” scores.

articles.headline: Boris Johnson Drops Bid to Return as U.K. Prime Minister
articles.snippet: Pulling out of the race to succeed Liz Truss, the former prime minister eased a path for Rishi Sunak, his former chancellor of Britain’s treasury.
articles.abstract: Pulling out of the race to succeed Liz Truss, the former prime minister eased a path for Rishi Sunak, his former chancellor of Britain’s treasury.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Boris Johnson pulled out of the race to succeed Liz Truss as Britain’s prime minister on Sunday evening, ending a quixotic bid to reclaim a job he lost three months ago amid a cascade of scandals, and leaving his rival, Rishi Sunak, in a commanding position to be the country’s next leader.

articles.headline: China’s Leader Now Wields Formidable Power. Who Will Say No to Him?
articles.snippet: Xi Jinping has created a new ruling elite packed with loyalist officials primed to elevate his agenda of bolstering national security and of turning China into a technological great power.
articles.abstract: Xi Jinping has created a new ruling elite packed with loyalist officials primed to elevate his agenda of bolstering national security and of turning China into a technological great power.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley, Keith Bradsher and Chang Che

articles.headline: Rishi Sunak, Now the Front-Runner for U.K. Prime Minister, Could Say, ‘I Told You So’
articles.snippet: Mr. Sunak’s warnings about inflation and his fiscal conservatism may have cost him the post in September. But now his accurate assessments are easing his path to Britain’s top job.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sunak’s warnings about inflation and his fiscal conservatism may have cost him the post in September. But now his accurate assessments are easing his path to Britain’s top job.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rishi Sunak is set to become Britain’s next prime minister. Follow our live updates.

articles.headline: Their America Is Vanishing. Like Trump, They Insist They Were Cheated.
articles.snippet: The white majority is fading, the economy is changing and there’s a pervasive sense of loss in districts where Republicans fought the outcome of the 2020 election.
articles.abstract: The white majority is fading, the economy is changing and there’s a pervasive sense of loss in districts where Republicans fought the outcome of the 2020 election.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Representative Troy Nehls of Texas voted last year to reject Donald J. Trump’s electoral defeat, many of his constituents back home in Fort Bend County were thrilled.
articles.byline: By Michael H. Keller and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Xi Tightens His Grip on China at a Difficult Economic Moment
articles.snippet: China said its economy grew 3.9 percent in the third quarter. But investors unnerved by Xi Jinping’s power grab — and his state-heavy agenda — sent Chinese shares tumbling.
articles.abstract: China said its economy grew 3.9 percent in the third quarter. But investors unnerved by Xi Jinping’s power grab — and his state-heavy agenda — sent Chinese shares tumbling.
articles.lead_paragraph: As China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, moved to extend his rule, he pushed out rivals who had been perceived as pro-business. He praised Marxism over markets. He placed security ahead of the economy.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Math Scores Fell in Nearly Every State, and Reading Dipped on National Exam
articles.snippet: The results, from what is known as the nation’s report card, offer the most definitive picture yet of the pandemic’s devastating impact on students.
articles.abstract: The results, from what is known as the nation’s report card, offer the most definitive picture yet of the pandemic’s devastating impact on students.
articles.lead_paragraph: U.S. students in most states and across almost all demographic groups have experienced troubling setbacks in both math and reading, according to an authoritative national exam released on Monday, offering the most definitive indictment yet of the pandemic’s impact on millions of schoolchildren.
articles.byline: By Sarah Mervosh and Ashley Wu

articles.headline: Starbucks Showdown in Boston Points to New Phase of Union Campaign
articles.snippet: The company moved to contain the labor push after it took off nationally. Now, with strikes and other tactics, organizers seek to regain momentum.
articles.abstract: The company moved to contain the labor push after it took off nationally. Now, with strikes and other tactics, organizers seek to regain momentum.
articles.lead_paragraph: For much of the summer, employees reliably turned up at a Starbucks near Boston University. But instead of going inside to serve coffee, they sat outside in lawn chairs — as part of a strike over what they said was retaliation for unionizing.

articles.headline: In Tim Ryan’s Ohio Senate Race, the D Is Often Silent
articles.snippet: Mr. Ryan, the Ohio Democrat who is challenging J.D. Vance, has turned the state into perhaps the country’s unlikeliest Senate battleground.
articles.abstract: Mr. Ryan, the Ohio Democrat who is challenging J.D. Vance, has turned the state into perhaps the country’s unlikeliest Senate battleground.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Tim Ryan is the kind of candidate who appears to put some thought into appearing to put no thought into appearances.

articles.headline: A Lonely Protest in Beijing Inspires Young Chinese to Find Their Voice
articles.snippet: As beginner dissenters, they’re timid and scared. But they are experiencing a quiet political awakening, unhappy about censorship, repression and “zero Covid.”
articles.abstract: As beginner dissenters, they’re timid and scared. But they are experiencing a quiet political awakening, unhappy about censorship, repression and “zero Covid.”
articles.lead_paragraph: A protester unfurled two banners on a highway overpass in central Beijing on Oct. 13, denouncing Xi Jinping as a “despotic traitor.” China’s censors went to great lengths to scrub the internet of any reference to the act of dissent, prohibiting all discussion and shutting down many offending social media accounts.

articles.headline: Why a Black Democratic City Won’t Have a Black Democrat in the House
articles.snippet: Shri Thanedar’s primary victory means that for the first time in nearly 70 years, Detroit may not send a Black representative to Washington.
articles.abstract: Shri Thanedar’s primary victory means that for the first time in nearly 70 years, Detroit may not send a Black representative to Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — On a recent sunny Saturday afternoon in a neighborhood park in the middle of this sprawling city, residents were distributing free backpacks for students heading back to school. Girls sat patiently under a pop-up tent to get their hair braided, while other children gleefully leaped and collided in an inflated bounce castle.
